{"statusCode":200,"message":"NewsAgent completed successfully","timestamp":"2025-10-29T12:07:13.525Z","source":"manual-invocation","data":{"storiesProcessed":9,"stories":[{"title":"Keep Android Open","url":"http://keepandroidopen.org/","score":1133,"author":"LorenDB","comments":302,"timestamp":"2025-10-29T04:03:41.000Z","source":"hacker-news"},{"title":"AWS to bare metal two years later: Answering your questions about leaving AWS","url":"https://oneuptime.com/blog/post/2025-10-29-aws-to-bare-metal-two-years-later/view","score":64,"author":"ndhandala","comments":30,"timestamp":"2025-10-29T11:14:38.000Z","source":"hacker-news","summary":"## Summary

The article details a company's experience transitioning from AWS to bare metal servers over a two-year period, addressing community questions that arose after their initial report of saving $230,000/year. They expanded to multiple data centers, maintained high availability (99.993%), improved performance with 19% lower latency, and significantly increased their cost savings to $1.2M/year. The piece tackles common criticisms about their approach, explaining why AWS cost-saving options like Reserved Instances weren't sufficient, and how they handled concerns about reliability, operational overhead, and disaster recovery with their bare metal infrastructure.

## Key Insight

The most valuable takeaway is that while cloud services provide convenience, companies with steady, predictable workloads can achieve dramatically higher cost efficiency (76% savings compared to AWS) through bare metal implementations without sacrificing reliabilityâ€”but this requires sufficient scale and engineering expertise to justify the operational complexity and upfront investment. Their expansion into AI infrastructure using the saved funds demonstrates how these savings can fuel strategic business growth rather than just reducing expenses.","audioUrl":"https://newsagent-audio-313117444016-us-west-2.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/audio/2025-10-29/aws-to-bare-metal-two-years-later-answering-your-q.mp3"},{"title":"Who needs Graphviz when you can build it yourself?","url":"https://spidermonkey.dev/blog/2025/10/28/iongraph-web.html","score":229,"author":"pdubroy","comments":33,"timestamp":"2025-10-29T05:17:49.000Z","source":"hacker-news","summary":"## Summary
The article discusses the development of a custom graph visualization tool for SpiderMonkey's Ion compiler, created to overcome limitations in existing tools like Graphviz. The author designed a specialized algorithm that produces stable, intuitive layouts for compiler optimization graphs. The new tool offers interactive features like zooming, highlighting, and timeline scrubbing to better visualize how JavaScript and WebAssembly code is processed and optimized.

## Key Insight
Unlike general-purpose graph layout tools that produce unstable and counterintuitive visualizations, the author's custom algorithm maintains stable node positions across compiler optimization passes, allowing developers to track specific code elements as they transform. This stability dramatically improves the debugging experience by preserving spatial context even as the underlying graph structure evolves - solving a fundamental problem in compiler visualization that standard tools like Graphviz couldn't address.","audioUrl":"https://newsagent-audio-313117444016-us-west-2.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/audio/2025-10-29/who-needs-graphviz-when-you-can-build-it-yourself-.mp3"},{"title":"ChatGPT Desktop App","url":"https://openai.com/chatgpt/desktop","score":225,"author":"Product Hunt","comments":49,"timestamp":"2025-10-29T12:07:14.123Z","source":"product-hunt","summary":"## Summary
